questions.text: A 20-year-old female came in with the following findings. He complains of a slight burning sensation in the eyes. History revealed one episode of a gouty attack 3 weeks ago. Which of the following is not a correct statement regarding the pathophysiology of the disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Diffuse injection occurs in 30% of cases

options.label: C
options.text: If it lasts for >3 weeks, a systemic workup is mandatory

options.label: D
options.text: Once collagen has been destroyed, inflammation recedes, uvea herniates into the defect

questions.correct_answer: D. Once collagen has been destroyed, inflammation recedes, uvea herniates into the defect
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Once collagen has been destroyed, inflammation recedes, uvea herniates into the defect The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of episcleritis . Sectoral involvement can be seen in the Image. The patient is a young adult female with gouty tendency thus making the diagnosis of episcleritis more favourable. In scleritis , the following findings are common: zonal necrotizing granuloma, fibrinoid necrosis.

Highyeild:

Systemic disorders associated with Episcleritis include collagen-vascular diseases (rheumatoid arthritis, Crohn’s disease, ulcerative colitis, psoriatic arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus, reactive arthritis (formerly Reiter’s syndrome), relapsing polychondritis, ankylosing spondylitis, and pustulotic arthro-osteitis), vasculitides (polyarteritis nodosa, temporal arteritis, Cogan’s syndrome, Churg-Strauss syndrome, granulomatosis with polyangiitis, Behcet’s disease), dermatologic disease (rosacea, pyoderma gangrenosum, Sweet’s syndrome), metabolic disease (gout), and atopy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: Option: A. Chronic inflammation , diffuse involvement in 30% of cases. fusiform thickening, immune complex deposition with complement activation Once collagen has been destroyed, inflammation recedes, and uvea herniates into defects. Option: B. When differentiating episcleritis from scleritis , the phenylephrine blanching technique can be used. It works on the concept of blanching congested conjunctival and superficial episcleral blood vessels with either the 2.5% or the 10% concentration. When the deep episcleral plexus does not blanch, the diagnosis is usually scleritis. Option: C. Episcleritis is a relatively common, benign, self-limited inflammation of the episcleral tissues. However, if the condition does not resolve in 3 weeks , a systemic workup should be done to rule out systemic involvement. Approximately 26-36% of patients have an associated systemic disorder. The most common collagen vascular disease association is with rheumatoid arthritis. Malignancies, usually T-cell leukaemia and Hodgkin’s lymphoma, can be associated with episcleritis. Foreign bodies and chemical injuries can also serve as inciting factors.

Extraedge:

The inflammatory response is localized to the superficial episcleral vascular network , and histopathology shows non-granulomatous inflammation with vascular dilatation and perivascular infiltration.

questions.text: An elderly male was referred to the ophthalmology department during an annual exam with the following finding. The patient is otherwise healthy and has no other complaints. He denies any comorbidities and reports that he has noticed this finding before but chose to ignore it due to the absence of distressing symptoms. What is your clinical impression?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cogan’s plaque Cogan’s Senile Scleral Plaque- blue-grey hyalinization of sclera anterior to horizontal rectus muscle insertions Symptoms: have no clinical significance

Highyeild:

Signs: Bilateral, symmetric, sharply demarcated vertically ovoid , or sometimes rectangular zones of increased scleral translucency Commonly situated just in front of the medial and lateral recti It may undergo calcification and become opaque white.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Ochronosis (Alkaptonuria): Homogentisic acid accumulates and is metabolized into melanin-like compounds with brown pigmentation of cartilage (ear, nose, heart valves) and sclera. Findings-triangular pigment deposits anterior to rectus muscle insertions, pinhead-sized peripheral corneal stromal deposits, pigmentation of tarsus and lids Option: C. Ocular Melanocytosis: uncommon condition increase in number, size and pigmentation of melanocytes in the sclera and uvea-periocular skin, orbit, meninges and soft palate may also be involved Option: D. Scleral Icterus-yellow sclera caused by hyperbilirubinemia

Extraedge:

Cogan syndrome is a systemic collagen vascular disease and is associated with Episcleritis .

questions.text: A 23-year-old female came in with the following eye finding. She reports an acute onset of a burning sensation in the eye and redness along with mild tearing. She reports 3 previous episodes, self-limiting in nature. Her past medical history reveals a history of lupus, well controlled. She denies any other complaints. What is your clinical impression?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Episcleritis Episcleritis is an inflammatory condition affecting the episcleral tissue that lies between the conjunctiva and the sclera. It is usually a mild and self-limiting but recurrent disease. Most cases are idiopathic, although up to one-third have an underlying systemic condition. The Image shows sectoral involvement. The pathophysiology is poorly understood. The inflammatory response is localized to the superficial episcleral vascular network, and histopathology shows non-granulomatous inflammation with vascular dilatation and perivascular infiltration.

Highyeild:

A systemic disorder associated with Episcleritis includes collagen-vascular diseases (rheumatoid arthritis, Crohn’s disease, ulcerative colitis, psoriatic arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus, reactive arthritis (formerly Reiter’s syndrome), relapsing polychondritis, ankylosing spondylitis, and pustulotic arthro-osteitis), vasculitides (polyarteritis nodosa, temporal arteritis, Cogan’s syndrome, Churg-Strauss syndrome, granulomatosis with polyangiitis, Behcet’s disease), dermatologic disease (rosacea, pyoderma gangrenosum, Sweet’s syndrome), metabolic disease (gout), and atopy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: Option: A. It is important to differentiate episcleritis from scleritis since they differ in terms of prognosis and their association with systemic diseases. Scleritis, which is much less common than episcleritis, is more commonly associated with connective tissue or vasculitic diseases than episcleritis. Moreover, ocular complications such as decreased vision, anterior uveitis, peripheral ulcerative keratitis, and ocular hypertension are more commonly seen in scleritis than in episcleritis. Option: C. Phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis is a nodular inflammation of the cornea or conjunctiva that results from a hypersensitivity reaction to a foreign antigen. It was historically seen in poor, malnourished children with positive tuberculin skin tests. Currently, microbial proteins of Staphylococcus aureus are the most common causative antigens in phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis. Risk factors for S. aureus exposure include chronic blepharitis and suppurative keratitis. Option: D. Ochronosis (Alkaptonuria): Homogentisic acid accumulates and is metabolized into melanin-like compounds with brown pigmentation of cartilage (ear, nose, heart valves) and sclera. Findings- triangular pigment deposits anterior to rectus muscle insertions, pinhead-sized peripheral corneal stromal deposits, pigmentation of tarsus and lids

questions.text: A 35-year-old female came in with redness of the sclera and conjunctiva, photophobia and tearing. After investigations, the patient was diagnosed with necrotizing scleritis. Which of the following is not an appropriate step for management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Peri ocular steroid injections Periocular steroid injections may be used in non-necrotizing scleritis , but it is contraindicated in necrotizing disease. If disease control is inadequate with steroids alone, immunosuppressives (Eg: Cyclophosphamide, azathioprine, methotrexate and/or immunomodulators may be considered for treatment).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. In infective scleritis , if the infective agent is identified, topical or systemic antibiotics may be prescribed. Option: C. In mild to moderate cases of scleritis, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs such as flurbiprofen, indomethacin or ibuprofen may be prescribed for pain relief Option: D. Surgery may be indicated if scleral perforation or excessive scleral thinning is present. Bandage contact lenses or corneal glue may be used to repair damaged corneal tissue in the eye and preserve the patient's vision. If not treated, scleritis can cause blindness.

questions.text: A 57-year-old female comes in with ocular redness progressing a few days later to pain that may radiate to the face and temple. The discomfort wakes the patient in the early hours of the morning, improves later in the day and responds poorly to common analgesics. She also complained of blurring of vision. On examination, the below Image was noted. Which of the following is incorrect about this patient’s condition?

options.label: A
options.text: The average duration of the disease is around 6 years

options.label: B
options.text: As the oedema resolves, the affected area often takes on a slight grey/blue appearance

options.label: C
options.text: Nodules have a deeper blue–red colour and are immobile

options.label: D
options.text: Instillation of 10% phenylephrine drops will constrict the vasculature and the deep plexus overlying the nodule

questions.correct_answer: D. Instillation of 10% phenylephrine drops will constrict the vasculature and the deep plexus overlying the nodule
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Instillation of 10% phenylephrine drops will constrict the vasculature and the deep plexus overlying the nodule The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Anterior non-necrotizing scleritis, diffuse type . Diffuse disease is slightly more common in females and usually presents in the fifth decade . Instillation of 10% phenylephrine drops will constrict the conjunctival and superficial episcleral vasculature but not the deep plexus overlying the nodule. In scleritis , the following findings are common: zonal necrotizing granuloma, fibrinoid necrosis.

Highyeild:

Systemic disorders associated with Episcleritis include collagen-vascular diseases (rheumatoid arthritis, Crohn’s disease, ulcerative colitis, psoriatic arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus, reactive arthritis (formerly Reiter’s syndrome), relapsing polychondritis, ankylosing spondylitis, and pustulotic arthro-osteitis), vasculitides (polyarteritis nodosa, temporal arteritis, Cogan’s syndrome, Churg-Strauss syndrome, granulomatosis with polyangiitis, Behcet’s disease), dermatologic disease (rosacea, pyoderma gangrenosum, Sweet’s syndrome), metabolic disease (gout), and atopy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. The average duration of the disease is around 6 years, with the frequency of recurrences decreasing after the first 18 months. The long-term visual prognosis is good. Option: B. As the oedema resolves, the affected area often takes on a slight grey/blue appearance because of increased scleral translucency. This is due to the rearrangement of scleral fibres rather than a decrease in scleral thickness. Option: C. Scleral nodules may be single or multiple and most frequently develop in the interpalpebral region close to the limbus; as seen in the Image given. They have a deeper blue–red colour than episcleral nodules and are immobile.

Extraedge:

The inflammatory response is localized to the superficial episcleral vascular network , and histopathology shows non-granulomatous inflammation with vascular dilatation and perivascular infiltration.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female comes in with ocular redness progressing 2 weeks later to pain that may radiate to the face and temple. She also complained of blurring of vision, redness, tearing and photophobia. On examination, the below Image was noted. What is your initial impression?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vaso-occlusive necrotizing scleritis The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of vaso-occlusive necrotizing scleritis Signs vary according to the following three types of necrotizing scleritis. Vaso-occlusive is commonly associated with rheumatoid arthritis. Isolated patches of scleral oedema with overlying non-perfused episclera and conjunctiva are seen in the earlier stage.

Highyeild:

The patches coalesce and if unchecked rapidly proceed to scleral necrosis as seen in the given Image.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Episcleritis is a common, usually idiopathic and benign, recurrent and frequently bilateral condition. Females may be affected more commonly than males, except possibly in children, in whom episcleritis is rare. The average patient is middle-aged. It is typically self-limiting and tends to last from a few days up to 3 weeks, but rarely longer. Option: C. Granuloma formation may occur in conjunction with conditions such as granulomatosis with polyangiitis or polyarteritis nodosa. The disease typically starts with an injection adjacent to the limbus and then extends posteriorly. Within 24 hours, the sclera, episclera, conjunctiva and adjacent cornea become irregularly raised and oedematous. Option: D. Surgically induced scleritis typically starts within 3 weeks of a procedure, though much longer intervals have been reported. It may be induced by any type of surgery including strabismus repair, trabeculectomy with excessive exposure to mitomycin C, excision of pterygium and scleral buckling.

Extraedge:

The necrotizing process starts at the site of surgery and extends outwards, but tends to remain localized to one sector.

questions.text: An elderly female came in with dry eyes and itchiness. There is no blurring of vision. Examination findings are seen in the Image below. Past medical history revealed a long-standing history of rheumatoid arthritis. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Scleromalacia perforans The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Scleromalacia perforans . The image shows severe thinning and exposure of underlying uvea due to progression to the later stage of the disease. Scleromalacia perforans is a specific type of progressive scleral thinning without inflammation that typically affects elderly women with longstanding rheumatoid arthritis, but has also been described in association with other systemic disorders.

Highyeild:

Despite the nomenclature, perforation of the globe is rare as integrity is maintained by a thin layer of fibrous tissue.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Posterior scleritis is a potentially blinding condition in which diagnosis is commonly delayed, with an adverse prognostic effect. The inflammatory changes in posterior and anterior scleral disease are identical and can arise in both segments simultaneously or separately. The age at onset is often less than 40 years. Pain does not correlate well with the severity of inflammation but tends to be more severe in those with accompanying orbital myositis. Option: C. Surgically induced scleritis typically starts within 3 weeks of a procedure , though much longer intervals have been reported. It may be induced by any type of surgery including strabismus repair, trabeculectomy with excessive exposure to mitomycin C , excision of pterygium and scleral buckling. The necrotizing process starts at the site of surgery and extends outwards, but tends to remain localized to one sector. Option: D. Episcleritis is a common , usually idiopathic and benign, recurrent and frequently bilateral condition. Females may be affected more commonly than males, except possibly in children, in whom episcleritis is rare. The average patient is middle-aged. It is typically self-limiting and tends to last from a few days up to 3 weeks, but rarely longer.

Extraedge:

Pain is absent and vision unaffected and keratoconjunctivitis sicca may be suspected.

questions.text: The sclera is the fibrous covering of the eye that shows up as a dense white layer beneath the transparent conjunctiva. Which of these statements regarding the vascularity of this layer is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Arteries are straight and veins are tortuous

options.label: B
options.text: In episcleritis, maximal congestion occurs in the deep vascular plexus

options.label: C
options.text: Purplish hue is seen in the conjunctival vessels in episcleritis

options.label: D
options.text: Conjunctival vessels are the most superficial

questions.correct_answer: D. Conjunctival vessels are the most superficial
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Conjunctival vessels are the most superficial The scleral stroma is composed of collagen bundles of varying size and shape that are not uniformly oriented as in the cornea and so are not transparent. The inner layer of the sclera (lamina fusca) blends with the uveal tract. Anteriorly the episclera consists of a connective tissue layer between the superficial scleral stroma and Tenon capsule.

Highyeild:

There are three pre-equatorial vascular layers : Conjunctival vessels: Conjunctival vessels are the most superficial. Superficial episcleral plexus Deep vascular plexus

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Conjunctival vessels are the most superficial. Arteries are tortuous and veins are straight. Option: B. Superficial episcleral plexus vessels are straight with a radial configuration. In episcleritis, maximal congestion occurs at this level. Topical phenylephrine 2.5% will constrict the conjunctival and 10% of the superficial episcleral vessels. Option: C. The deep vascular plexus lies in the superficial part of the sclera and shows maximal congestion in scleritis. A purplish hue, best seen in daylight, is characteristic.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male comes in with a history of progressive pain and redness along with mild photophobia. On the exam, you notice the following findings. Which of the following is not true about the layer of the external eye affected in the patient’s condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Posterior apertures are situated around the optic nerve and transmit long and short ciliary nerves and vessels

options.label: B
options.text: It is an avascular structure which consists of dense bundles of collagen fibres

options.label: C
options.text: It is thickest at the insertion of extraocular muscles

options.label: D
options.text: Its whole outer surface is covered by Tenon’s capsule

questions.correct_answer: C. It is thickest at the insertion of extraocular muscles
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It is thickest at the insertion of extraocular muscles The given case history and case findings point to the diagnosis of anterior necrotising scleritis with inflammation . In the given Image, underlying blue uveal tissue is visible giving redness a ‘violaceous’ hue. Primarily, the sclera is affected in this condition. The thickness of the sclera varies considerably in different individuals and with the age of the person. It is generally thinner in children than adults and in females than the males.

Highyeild:

The sclera is thickest posteriorly (1 mm) and gradually becomes thin when traced anteriorly. It is thinnest at the insertion of extraocular muscles (0.3 mm)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Sclera is pierced by three sets of apertures: Posterior apertures are situated around the optic nerve and transmit long and short ciliary nerves and vessels. Middle apertures (four in number) are situated slightly posterior to the equator; through this pass the four vortex veins (vena varicose). Anterior apertures are situated 3 to 4 mm away from the limbus. Anterior ciliary vessels and branches from long ciliary nerves pass through these apertures. Option: B. Sclera proper is an avascular structure which consists of dense bundles of collagen fibres . The bands of collagen tissue cross each other in all directions. Option: D. Sclera forms the posterior five-sixth opaque part of the external fibrous tunic of the eyeball. Its whole outer surface is covered by Tenon’s capsule. In the anterior part, it is also covered by the bulbar conjunctiva.

Extraedge:

Apertures in the sclera. (posterior view): SCN, short ciliary nerve; SPCA, short posterior ciliary artery, LPCA. long posterior ciliary artery, VG, vena verticosa

questions.text: A 54-year-old male came in with ocular redness, pain and chemosis. The exam findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following diseases is not have a significant association with it?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Iron deficiency anaemia The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of anterior scleritis, non-necrotising type . Iron deficiency anaemia is not associated with the occurrence of scleritis. The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Anterior non-necrotizing scleritis, diffuse type . Diffuse disease is slightly more common in females and usually presents in the fifth decade . Instillation of 10% phenylephrine drops will constrict the conjunctival and superficial episcleral vasculature but not the deep plexus overlying the nodule. In scleritis , the following findings are common: zonal necrotizing granuloma, fibrinoid necrosis.

Highyeild:

Systemic disorders associated with Episcleritis include collagen-vascular diseases (rheumatoid arthritis, Crohn’s disease, ulcerative colitis, psoriatic arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus, reactive arthritis (formerly Reiter’s syndrome), relapsing polychondritis, ankylosing spondylitis, and pustulotic arthro-osteitis), vasculitides (polyarteritis nodosa, temporal arteritis, Cogan’s syndrome, Churg-Strauss syndrome, granulomatosis with polyangiitis, Behcet’s disease), dermatologic disease (rosacea, pyoderma gangrenosum, Sweet’s syndrome), metabolic disease (gout), and atopy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. The autoimmune disease rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is the most common systemic association of scleritis and is characterized by a symmetrical deforming inflammatory polyarthropathy , with a spectrum of possible extra-articular manifestations. Presentation is commonly in the third decade with joint swelling, usually of the hands. It is much more common in females than males. Rheumatoid factor antibodies are present in 80–90%. All forms of immune-mediated scleritis have been described in RA and the clinical course is often more aggressive than when there is no systemic association. Other ocular manifestations of RA include keratoconjunctivitis sicca (secondary Sjögren syndrome), s and acquired superior oblique tendon sheath syndrome (very rare). Option: C. Crohn's disease is a chronic, relapsing inflammatory bowel disease of unknown cause. Extraintestinal complications occur frequently during the course of the disease. The commonest of these are peripheral arthritis and erythema nodosum . The eye is involved in 4% to 10% of patients and a wide spectrum of inflammatory conditions may be found. Acute episcleritis, acute anterior Uveitis and marginal keratitis are the commonest manifestations, although conjunctivitis, optic neuritis, orbital inflammatory disease and retinal vasculitis have been reported. Acute anterior scleritis is rare and may be complicated by the development of scleromalacia perforans . Acute episcleritis and increased bowel activity show a close correlation. Option: D. Relapsing polychondritis is a rare idiopathic condition characterized by small vessel vasculitis involving cartilage resulting in recurrent, often progressive, inflammatory episodes involving multiple organ systems such as the ears, nasal cartilage, respiratory system, heart and joints. Presentation is frequently in middle age. Scleritis is often intractable and may be necrotizing or non-necrotizing . Isolated anterior uveitis may also occur.

The inflammatory response is localized to the superficial episcleral vascular network , and histopathology shows non-granulomatous inflammation with vascular dilatation and perivascular infiltration.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male came in with severe ocular pain, tearing, periocular edema and mild proptosis. B-scan USG was done revealing sclera thickening as shown in the image below. What is your clinical impression?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Posterior scleritis The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of posterior scleritis . The B-scan ultrasonography Image given is showing scleral thickening and fluid in the sub-Tenon space (arrow), with the characteristic ‘T’ sign. Ultrasonography may show increased scleral thickness, scleral nodules, separation of Tenon capsule from the sclera, disc oedema, choroidal folds and retinal detachment.

Highyeild:

Fluid in the Tenon space may give a characteristic ‘T’ sign , the stem of the T being formed by the optic nerve and the crossbar by the fluid-containing gap.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Subretinal mass: Alternative lesions include miscellaneous granulomatous conditions and choroidal neoplasia. Option: B. Orbital cellulitis may cause proptosis and periocular oedema but is associated with marked pyrexia. Option: D. Exudative retinal detachment occurs in around 25% of cases of posterior scleritis. The yellowish-brown subretinal exudative material can be mistaken for a choroidal tumour.

Extraedge:

MRI and CT may show scleral thickening and proptosis.

questions.text: Staphyloma refers to a localised bulging of the weak and thin outer tunic of the eyeball (cornea or sclera), lined by uveal tissue. Match the following types of staphyloma with the given characteristics: Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

a-1, b-3, c-4, d-2 Anterior staphyloma: An ectasia of the pseudo cornea (the scar formed from organized exudates and fibrous tissue covered with epithelium) which results after total sloughing of the cornea , with the iris plastered behind it is called anterior staphyloma . Intercalary staphyloma: It is the name given to the localised bulge in the limbal area lined by the root of the iris. It results due to ectasia of weak scar tissue formed at the limbus, following the healing of a perforating injury or a peripheral corneal ulcer.

Highyeild:

Secondary angle-closure glaucoma may cause the progression of bulge if not treated. Defective vision occurs due to marked corneal astigmatism. Treatment consists of localised staphylectomy under heavy doses of oral steroids. Ciliary staphyloma: As the name implies, it is the bulge of a weak sclera lined by the ciliary body. It occurs about 2–3 mm away from the limbus. Its common causes are thinning of the sclera following perforating injury, scleritis and absolute glaucoma. Equatorial staphyloma: It results due to a bulge of sclera lined by the choroid in the equatorial region Its causes are scleritis and degeneration of the sclera in pathological myopia.

Staphyloma is diagnosed on The area is excavated with retinal vessels dipping in it (just like marked cupping of the optic disc in glaucoma ). Its floor is focused with minus lenses in the ophthalmoscope as compared to its margins.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male came in with redness and tearing. On examination, you noticed scleral nodules in an annular fashion around the limbus. The findings are shown in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Non-necrotizing anterior nodular scleritis The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Non-necrotizing anterior nodular scleritis It is characterised by one or two hard, purplish elevated immovable scleral nodules as shown in the given figure, and is usually situated near the limbus.

Highyeild:

Sometimes, the nodules are arranged in a ring around the limbus as seen in this case (annular scleritis)

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Anterior necrotizing scleritis with inflammation: It is an acute severe form of scleritis characterised by intense localised inflammation associated with areas of infarction due to vasculitis. The affected necrosed area is thinned out and the sclera becomes transparent and ectatic with uveal tissue shining through it. It is usually associated with anterior uveitis . Option: C. Anterior necrotizing scleritis without inflammation (scleromalacia perforans): This specific entity typically occurs in elderly females usually suffering from longstanding rheumatoid arthritis. It is characterised by development of yellowish patch of melting sclera (due to obliteration of arterial supply); which often together with the overlying episclera and conjunctiva completely separates from the surrounding normal sclera. This sequestrum of sclera becomes dead white in colour, which eventually absorbs leaving behind it a large punched out area of thin sclera through which the uveal tissue shines. Spontaneous perforation is extremely rare. Option: D. Posterior scleritis: It is an inflammation involving the sclera behind the equator. The condition is frequently misdiagnosed. It is characterised by features of associated inflammation of adjacent structures, which include: Exudative retinal detachment, Macular oedema, Proptosis and Limitation of ocular movements

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient was diagnosed with rapidly progressive necrotizing scleritis, granulomatous in origin. The patient was found to have the following findings on a systemic exam. Which of these diseases are associated with this patient’s condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Granulomatosis With Polyangiitis The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Granulomatosis with polyangiitis The Image is showing nasal collapse and a convergent squint secondary to extensive sinus disease Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener granulomatosis) is an idiopathic multisystem granulomatous disorder characterized by small vessel vasculitis typically affecting primarily the paranasal sinuses lower respiratory tract, the kidneys and skin.

Highyeild:

There is a male predominance . Presentation is in the fifth decade on average, often with pulmonary symptoms. Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (cANCA) are found in over 90% of patients with active disease. Scleritis is often rapidly progressive, necrotizing and granulomatous.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. The autoimmune disease rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is the most common systemic association of scleritis and is characterized by a symmetrical deforming inflammatory polyarthropathy, with a spectrum of possible extra-articular manifestations. Presentation is commonly in the third decade with joint swelling, usually of the hands. It is much more common in females than males. Rheumatoid factor autoantibodies are present in 80–90%. All forms of immune-mediated scleritis have been described in RA and the clinical course is often more aggressive than when there is no systemic association. Other ocular manifestations of RA include keratoconjunctivitis sicca (secondary Sjögren syndrome), ulcerative keratitis and acquired superior oblique tendon sheath syndrome (very rare). Option: C. Crohn’s disease is a chronic, relapsing inflammatory bowel disease of unknown cause. Extraintestinal complications occur frequently during the course of the disease. The commonest of these are peripheral arthritis and erythema nodosum. The eye is involved in 4% to 10% of patients and a wide spectrum of inflammatory conditions may be found./li> Acute episcleritis , acute anterior Uveitis and marginal keratitis are the commonest manifestations, although conjunctivitis, optic neuritis, orbital inflammatory disease and retinal vasculitis have been reported. Acute anterior scleritis is rare and may be complicated by the development of scleromalacia perforans. Acute episcleritis and increased bowel activity show a close correlation. Option: D. Relapsing polychondritis is a rare idiopathic condition characterized by small vessel vasculitis involving cartilage resulting in recurrent, often progressive, inflammatory episodes involving multiple organ systems such as the ears, nasal cartilage, respiratory system, heart and joints. Presentation is frequently in middle age. Scleritis is often intractable and may be necrotizing or non-necrotizing. Isolated anterior uveitis may also occur.

Extraedge:

Other ocular manifestations include peripheral ulcerative keratitis, occlusive retinal vasculitis, orbital inflammatory disease, nasolacrimal obstruction, dacryocystitis and, rarely, tarsal–conjunctival disease

questions.text: A 30-year-old male came in with an insidious onset of pain followed by increasing redness, tenderness of the globe and the appearance of a scleral nodule. He also complained of blurring of vision. Past medical history revealed previous attacks of herpes zoster ophthalmicus. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Immune-Mediated Anterior Non-necrotizing Scleritis The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Immune-Mediated Anterior Non-necrotizing Scleritis . Scleral nodules may be single or multiple and most frequently develop in the interpalpebral region close to the limbus. They have a deeper blue–red colour than episcleral nodules and are immobile .

Highyeild:

The incidence of nodular and diffuse anterior scleritis is the same but a disproportionately large number of those with nodular disease have had a previous attack of herpes zoster ophthalmicus. The age of onset is similar to that of diffuse scleritis.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. The necrotizing disease is an aggressive form of scleritis. The age at onset is later than that of non-necrotizing scleritis, averaging 60 years . The condition is bilateral in 60% of patients and unless appropriately treated, especially in its early stages, may result in severe visual morbidity and even loss of the eye. Option: B. Surgically induced scleritis typically starts within 3 weeks of a procedure, though much longer intervals have been reported. It may be induced by any type of surgery including strabismus repair, trabeculectomy with excessive exposure to mitomycin C, excision of pterygium and scleral buckling. The necrotizing process starts at the site of surgery and extends outwards, but tends to remain localized to one sector. Option: D. Granuloma formation may occur in conjunction with conditions such as granulomatosis with polyangiitis or polyarteritis nodosa . The disease typically starts with an injection adjacent to the limbus and then extends posteriorly. Within 24 hours, the sclera, episclera, conjunctiva and adjacent cornea become irregularly raised and oedematous

options.label: D

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Episcleritis Episcleritis is a benign recurrent inflammation of the episclera , involving the overlying Tenon’s capsule but not the underlying sclera. A typical nodule of episcleritis is flat, pink or purple, surrounded by injection and is usually situated 2 to 3 mm away from the limbus.

Episcleritis is a common , usually idiopathic and benign, recurrent and frequently bilateral condition. Females may be affected more commonly than males, except possibly in children, in whom episcleritis is rare. The average patient is middle-aged.
